title: Yosemite National Park: Backpacking
body: Backpacking        Backpackers look toward Merced Lake and the back of Half Dome. Kenny Karst       "Thousands of tired, nerve-shaken, over-civilized people are beginning to find out that going to the mountains is going home; that wildness is a necessity..." --John Muir, 1898      Nearly 95 percent of Yosemite National Park is designated Wilderness. Wilderness is a special distinction granted by Congress protecting land from further development. The best way to experience the 1,100 square miles of the Yosemite Wilderness is to explore it first hand. Plan your Backpacking Trip  Trail descriptions, current trail conditions, and seasonal information  Wilderness permits (required for overnight trips) Food storage and other regulations Safety tips and Leave No Trace ethics Trailhead information, including parking and transportation  Backpacking with a large group  Backpacking in winter and spring Hiking the John Muir Trail (JMT) or Pacific Crest Trail (PCT) Overnight trips to Half Dome and Little Yosemite Valley (LYV) Traveling with a horse or pack animal  Curious what "wilderness" means?
